cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities, current accounts opened. Receives money on deposit at sight at 3% per annum.

Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: Sale of Torpedo Boats.
div.p: Sealed teners (in duplicate) will be recieved at this Dockyard up to midday, Friday, November 29th, for the purchaseand removal -without restrictionss - of SIX SECOND CLASS TORPEDO BOATS, complete with BOILERS and ENGINES , and built by THE YARROW SHIPBUILDING CO.,in 1889
The Boats may be inspected at the Dockyard on application being made to the Admiral Superintendent.
Permission will not be given for the Boats to be broken up in the Dockyard.
Envelopes should be clearly marked"TENDER FOR TORPEDO BOATS," and addressed to the Admiral Superintendent.
The Admiral Superindent does not bind himself to accept the highest or any tender.
F.W Fisher
31140-2*-1 Admiral Superintendent

div.head: 60 STONES
div.p: Years of Awful Agony
Cured by Doan's Backache Kidney Pills
When interviewed - 18 months after her cure - by one of our representatives, Mrs. M. Hughes, 70, Latimer Street, Liverpool, England, said: - "I am most pleased to endorsed my previous statement"

The following is the story of Mrs. Hughes' illness, in her own words: "I first had medical treatment nine years ago, and the doctor tole me that my trouble arose from the kidneys and that it would be necessary to draw the water from my body with an instrument; my back was frightful. For nearly three years before I called in the doctor I had been suffering from stabbing pains that used to strike right across the small of me back, At times I would have to stand to gte my breath until the pain eased - it was like a knife being driven into my back. When at last I saw the doctor the pains were so bad and I was in such a serious state that I had taken to my bed. I also suffered terribly from urinary troubles. I ailed all over, suffering from a terrible pressing pain at the top of my head, which made me feel as if it would finally drive me demented; there were also shooting pains in the temples, rheumatic pains, hot flushes and cold chills, and I used to have a dragging, tired feeling which made me disinclined to go out of doors at all of even talk to anybody.

"Off and on the doctor treated me for three years, similar attacks coming on all the time then I tired a second doctor, and I at last I made up my mind to see what Doan's Backache Kidney Pills would do for me. I used two boxes and obtained no relief, and began to fear that they would do me no good. But toward the nend of the third box the urine began to pass more freely. After that stones began to come away, at first small, about the size of peas, and after that larger, some of them as large as a small bean. There was great pain while passing them, but otherwise I began to feel much better. In all I passed 60 stones, using the pills for months according to directions. My health has been first-rate ever since.

Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 13 P.T. per box, or 71 P.T for 6 boxes; or they may be had direct from the agents for Eygpt, Mr. E. Del Mar, Rue Hotel du Nil, and Rue Mousky, Cario Rue Tewfik, (opposite the Bourse), Alexandria and Rue Commerciale, Port Said; and Messers S. Fischer, and Co., Rue Sheriff Pacha, Alexandria.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.

div.head: The Eygptian Gazette
div.p: The English Dailey Newspaper
Established 1880
Editor and Manager - - R.Snelling
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
Monday, October 21, 1907.
DANGERS OF MODERATE DRINKING

The effect of a small daily dose of alcohol on animals is set forth by Professor Taav. LAitinen, of Helsingtors, in a paper laid before the International Anti-Alcohol Congress at Stockholm, of which an account is given by Mr. Theodore Neild in the "British Journal of Inebreity"

"Prof. Laitinen began by reminding us that former results which he had from time to time published had been obtained by the administration of larger doses - never less than 0.5 gramme for each kilogramme that the animal in question weighed. He had felt that it was of great importance, however, to try how far the resistivity of animals was effected, and in what directions, when the doses administered each day were so small as 0.1 gramme

"The writer, when at Helsingfors, was told by Prof. Laitinen that this amount would mean, in the case of a man of average weight, a glass of Finnish beer daily, and the glass seemed hardly as large as that used in England. In order to detect the influence of these very small does, Prof. Laitinen has kept his research animals - guinea pigs and rabits - in a perfectly equipped place. He employed a large number of animals, and, of course, treated them all alike, even to the handling during the administration of the liquids. The only difference was that some had water alone, and others the same quantity of water with such an amount of alcohol mixed with it as to get 0.1 gramme of alcohol per kilogramme of their respective weights. The two sets were treated for eight months. To dect the altercation in resistivity, Dr. Laitien availed himself of the most delicate methods of reseach and biological reactions. In the first place, the resistivity of the animals (the alcoholised animals and the control or non-alcoholised animals were tested either by autoinfection or by inoculation (guinea pigs) with the toxin of diphteria. This showed the alcoholised animals to have less resistivity. The difference was clearly to be recognised. In the case of fourty rabbits exxposed to infecion for four months the lessened immunity was as fourty-five to sixty-five, and where death ensured the duration of disease was as 13.6 to 21.7 days in the alcoholished and control animals respectively. . . .

Of the young born of alcoholised rabbits 61.29 per cent. deied and of those born of control animals 54.17 per cent. died. The young of the alcoholished rabbits, when three days old, weighed on a average 79 grammes, and grew during the next twenty days 7.13 grammes daily on an average. The young of those treated with water only, weighed 87.9 grammes at birth, and grew at the rate of 9.46 grammes per diem.

The difference is still clearer when we come to the guinea pigs. Of the young of those treated with water alone 21.74 per cent. only died; whilst, on the other hand, the proportion in the case of the alcoholised animals was 36.76 per cent. The progeny of the former weighed at birth on an average 77.31 grammes, grew in the first ten days 4.12 grammes daily. The young of the latter - the alcoholised animals- on the other hand, were on an average 73.41 grammes at birth, and grew in the first twenty days 4.30 grammes daily. When he carried on his weighings for 110 days the difference was as 4.36 grammes to 5.50 grammes. He began with seventy animals and ended with 348, having had more than 600 pass through his hands. It constitutes one of the most important reseaches of modern times, and its findings must exercise a great influence upon our attitude towards what is now regarded as the most moderate use of alcohol as a beverage"
